awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Universal skills for Geoscience Graduate Student Success in the Workforce
awd_abstract_narration:
Although geoscience professions have evolved with geoscience research and technology, different skills and competencies are needed by graduate students to be successful in the non-academic workforce. The investigators propose to determine the skills and competencies that should be part of graduate geoscience education, and the best means of developing these in graduate geoscience programs nationally. They will build on accomplishments from their previous initiative "The Future of Undergraduate Geoscience Education". This effort worked with geoscience employers and academics to identify skills, competencies and concepts needed by undergraduates to be successful in graduate school and the future workforce. Department heads and Chairs from across the country developed action plans for incorporating these results into their departments' undergraduate programs. 

For this activity, the investigators will hold an Employers Workshop with participants that span the breadth of geoscience professions to define the skills and competencies geoscience graduate students need to be successful in the workforce more broadly than academia. They will invite a range of employers from those actively involved in recruiting new hires to senior executives. Subsequently the investigators will organize a summit for departmental heads, chairs, and graduate program directors to discuss ways to implement change in individual departments and programs. Participants will be invited from a broad spectrum of earth, ocean, and atmospheric science programs at Masters and PhD granting institutions. An important outcome will be the transformation of graduate level curriculum for geoscience programs to better align course offerings and activities with future professional needs of earth, ocean and atmospheric sciences students.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
Geoscientists play a central role in addressing global and societal challenges. With the critical state of our global climate and need for reliable energy and mineral resources, water, and societal resilience to earth processes, the results of this project will have a long-term impact by helping ensure that the future geoscience workforce is prepared to meet these challenges. Geoscience professions in Earth, atmosphere and ocean sciences have evolved along with geoscience research and technology, and geoscience graduate students today need different skills and competencies than in the past to be successful in the workforce and to investigate and find solutions to these societal challenges.  In this project, we worked with over 300 geoscientists in the academic and employer communities and identified the universal skills and competencies needed for future success by geoscience graduate students, how students can develop these in their research, coursework and co-curricular activities, and better practices for mentoring.  This project builds on the outcomes of a previous NSF sponsored project on undergraduate geoscience education, reported in Vison and Change in the Geosciences: The Future of Undergraduate Geoscience Education (Mosher and Keane, 2021).

Essential skills include critical thinking, geoscientific and systems thinking, problem solving, communication to diverse audiences, teamwork and collaboration.  Also needed are quantitative and computational skills, including coding and programming, geostatistics and geospatial reasoning, data analytics and management, machine learning and artificial intelligence. Nontechnical skills include leadership, social dynamics, interpersonal skills, project and program management, business skills, ethics, the ability to learn, a growth mindset, and emotional intelligence. Finishing graduate students need to have a solid base of diverse, adaptable transferable skills.

Additionally in this project, we identified successful ways to integrate development of these skills into graduate education and to create change in graduate educational programs.  We also evaluated the roles of department heads and chairs, faculty, students, and external stakeholders (employers, alumni, professional societies, and funding agencies) and assessed ways in which all stakeholders can contribute to improving geoscience graduate education.

In a subaward, American Geoscience Institute survey responses created a better understanding of 1) the structure of U.S. graduate programs in Earth, atmosphere, and ocean sciences; 2) current student outcomes in terms of skills, employment, and co-curricular experiences; and 3) the status of graduate programs and the geoscience workforce, including trends in enrollments, degrees granted, employment, and current and future geoscience workforce and drivers for change.

A key outcome of this project is the 2023 publication of a comprehensive report: Vison and Change in the Geosciences: Shaping the Future of Graduate Geoscience Education, by Sharon Mosher, Jeffrey Ryan, and Christopher Keane that documents and discusses the all the key outcomes and recommendations from this initiative.  This publication has been disseminated to all departmental heads, chairs and graduate program directors in the U.S. who have the ability to implement changes to graduate programs to better prepare students for success.   Additionally, over 22,000 faculty, employers and leaders of geoscientific societies have been notified of the report and given free access to this publication (https://graduate.americangeosciences.org/). 

Broader Impacts: The outcomes of this project provide a roadmap for transformation of geoscience graduate programs across the country toward better aligning student education through research, coursework and co-curricular activities to the future professional needs of the Earth, atmospheric and ocean sciences.  This change will result in geoscience professionals who have the abilities to address societal challenges, including 1) making the transition to sustainable and environmentally responsible energy and food sources; and 2) forecasting and mitigating the dramatic economic and environmental impacts from the increase in the number of detrimental weather, climate, and oceanic events and from geohazards. 

Intellectual Merit: The outcomes of this project will have a major impact on the development of the Earth, atmospheric and ocean sciences through changes to graduate geoscience education. Geoscience graduate students will develop skills and competencies that will give them the ability to increase knowledge, conduct advanced research into new areas, use and develop new pedagogical methods, and apply these abilities successfully in the geoscience workforce.
